description: Continued use of second floor, above commercial unit, as self-contained flat (Use Class C3)
decision_conditions: The applicant has demonstrated, on the balance of probability, that the change of use to a self-contained flat (Class C3) was completed over 4 years ago and is therefore lawful under Section 171B(2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey rear/side extension. Erection of hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer, Juliet balcony and installation of 1no. side window to facilitate loft conversion, and 1no. side window at first floor levelConsultationThree neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire Safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Hip to gable roof extensions are not usually appropriate for semi detached dwellings due to unbalancing the symmetry between the properties, however, it is noted that the adjoining property benefits from a side dormer which has already caused harm to the symmetry.  The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed single storey side/rear would be a proportionate and subordinate addition.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to the existing situation between this site and its adjoining neighbours, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light. With regards to loss of privacy, any windows at first floor level or above in the eastern flank elevation should be provided with obscured glazing as per plan 2201 - P005 Elevations as Proposed. This would be secured by condition should permission be granted. Proposed areas of flat roof would be restricted from use as balconies/seating areas in order to secure neighbouring privacy. Noting the proposed raised patio area, it is considered necessary to require details of boundary treatment prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to ensure that privacy levels to neighbouring gardens are secured.Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments: While no Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021), Officers consider that the proposal should be able to meet the requirements of Policy D12(A). Were the application otherwise acceptable, a Fire Strategy would be secured by way of a planning condition. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Please provide all Existing and Proposed Elevations at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.
